lessons.title: Nurse Coach Foundation
lessons.subtitle: Bridging clinical expertise and coaching to transform patient outcomes

sections.content: Hey {name}! Welcome to your Certified Nurse Life Coach journey. As a nurse, you already have something that most coaches would kill for — clinical knowledge, patient rapport skills, and the trust that comes with being a healthcare professional. But right now, the system you work in is burning you out, underpaying you, and limiting the impact you can have. Nurse coaching changes all of that. It lets you use EVERYTHING you already know in a way that actually helps people heal — and pays you what you deserve.
What Is Nurse Coaching?

Nurse coaching is the practice of using your **clinical background combined with coaching skills** to help clients achieve lasting health and wellness outcomes. Unlike bedside nursing where you treat acute conditions in a broken system, nurse coaching allows you to work with clients one-on-one, addressing the root causes of their health struggles through education, behavior change, and ongoing support.

As a **Certified Nurse Life Coach**, you bridge the gap between what the healthcare system provides and what patients actually need. You help people who are falling through the cracks — the ones discharged from the hospital with a stack of pamphlets and zero follow-up, the ones managing chronic conditions with no real support, the ones who know they need to change but have no one to guide them.

Nurse coaching is NOT practicing nursing outside a clinical setting. It is using your nursing knowledge to educate, support, and empower clients to take ownership of their health. You are a guide, not a prescriber. A coach, not a clinician. And that distinction is what makes this career so freeing.
Why the Healthcare System Is Failing Patients

You already know this from the inside, {name}. The healthcare system is designed for **acute care**, not chronic wellness. Doctors have 7-minute appointments. Nurses are managing impossible patient-to-staff ratios. Patients leave the hospital confused, scared, and unsupported. The result? Readmissions, medication non-compliance, worsening chronic conditions, and people who feel completely abandoned by the system that was supposed to help them.
The healthcare gap in numbers:
items: Over **60%** of American adults have at least one chronic disease, and **40%** have two or more
Hospital readmission rates for chronic conditions remain stubbornly around **15-20%** within 30 days
The average doctor visit lasts **7 minutes** — not enough time to address lifestyle, nutrition, stress, or behavior change
**Nurse burnout** affects over 62% of nurses, with many leaving the profession entirely
The health coaching market is projected to exceed **$25 billion** by 2028, with nurse coaches among the highest-paid specialists

sections.content: Here is the opportunity: you have clinical credibility that non-nurse coaches do not have. When you say 'I am a nurse AND a certified health coach,' clients trust you instantly. You speak their language. You understand their medications, their conditions, and their fears. That combination is incredibly powerful — and incredibly rare.
The 5 Root Causes of Poor Health Outcomes

As a nurse, you have seen patients cycle through the healthcare system without improvement. The reason is almost always one or more of these five root causes that the medical system does not have time or training to address.
The 5 root causes you will address as a Nurse Life Coach:
items: **Lack of Health Literacy** — Most patients do not understand their conditions, their medications, or how lifestyle factors impact their health. They follow instructions without understanding why, which leads to non-compliance and frustration. You bridge this knowledge gap in a way their doctor does not have time to do.

**Behavior Change Resistance** — Knowing what to do and actually doing it are completely different things. Patients struggle with motivation, habit formation, emotional eating, stress management, and self-sabotage. Coaching science gives you tools to drive sustainable behavior change that prescriptions cannot.

**Chronic Stress and Burnout** — Stress is the invisible driver behind most chronic conditions. It elevates cortisol, disrupts sleep, triggers inflammation, weakens immunity, and destroys quality of life. Your clients need stress management strategies that go far beyond 'try to relax.'

**Post-Hospital Abandonment** — When patients leave the hospital or finish treatment, they enter a void. No one checks on them. No one helps them implement the discharge instructions. No one supports their recovery journey. You fill that critical gap.

**Whole-Person Neglect** — The medical system treats body parts, not people. It ignores the emotional, spiritual, relational, and lifestyle dimensions that are central to healing. As a nurse coach, you address the WHOLE person — mind, body, and spirit.

checkpoint.question: Which of the following is a root cause of poor health outcomes addressed by nurse coaching?
checkpoint.successMessage: Exactly! Post-hospital abandonment is one of the biggest gaps in healthcare. Patients are discharged with instructions but zero follow-up support. Nurse coaches fill that critical gap.

sections.content: Scope of Practice

This is especially important for nurses transitioning to coaching. As an ASI-certified **Nurse Life Coach**, your scope is distinct from your nursing license. You educate clients on health and wellness topics. You guide behavior change, habit formation, and lifestyle modifications. You support clients through chronic condition management, post-treatment recovery, and stress reduction. You empower clients to take ownership of their health journey.

You do NOT diagnose conditions, prescribe medications or treatments, provide nursing assessments outside of a clinical setting, or replace the care of a physician. Even though you are a nurse, your coaching practice operates within coaching scope. You refer to physicians, specialists, and mental health professionals when clinical intervention is needed. This clear boundary is what protects you AND gives you freedom.

revealCard.teaser: See how an ER nurse escaped burnout and built a $8,000/month coaching practice...
revealCard.content: Tamara was a 41-year-old ER nurse working 12-hour overnight shifts. She was burned out, underpaid, and watching patients cycle through the ER with the same preventable conditions month after month. After getting certified as a Nurse Life Coach, she started reaching out to former patients and hospital colleagues who were struggling with chronic conditions. Within 3 months she had 10 clients at $400/month. Within 8 months she had 20 clients and was earning over $8,000/month working from home during normal hours. She resigned from the hospital and says: 'I finally get to help patients the way I always wanted to — with time, attention, and real support.'

sections.content: Why YOUR Nursing Background Is Your Superpower

Let me be direct, {name}: your nursing background gives you an unfair advantage in the coaching world. You understand anatomy, physiology, pharmacology, and pathology. You know how to assess patients, communicate with medical teams, and handle crisis situations. You have the empathy that comes from years of caring for people at their most vulnerable. That clinical foundation combined with coaching skills creates a specialist that the market is desperate for.
Can you see yourself using your nursing expertise to help people in a whole new way — without the burnout, the night shifts, and the broken system?
What Is Coming Next

In the next lesson, you will learn the **D.E.P.T.H. Method** — the proprietary framework that gives you a structured, repeatable process for guiding every coaching client through assessment, behavior change, and lasting transformation. This system bridges your clinical knowledge with coaching methodology.

keyTakeaways: Nurse coaching bridges the gap between the healthcare system and what patients actually need — education, behavior change support, and ongoing guidance
Five root causes drive poor health outcomes: lack of health literacy, behavior change resistance, chronic stress, post-hospital abandonment, and whole-person neglect
Your nursing background gives you clinical credibility, patient rapport skills, and medical knowledge that non-nurse coaches cannot match

lessons.title: The D.E.P.T.H. Method™
lessons.subtitle: Your systematic framework for nurse coaching sessions

sections.content: Welcome back, {name}! In Lesson 1 you learned what nurse coaching is and the 5 root causes of poor health outcomes that the medical system fails to address. Now I am going to give you the exact framework that transforms your clinical expertise into a structured coaching practice — the system that has helped hundreds of nurses build thriving second careers.

This is the **D.E.P.T.H. Method** — adapted specifically for nurse coaches. It combines the assessment skills you already have with proven coaching methodology to create a process that feels natural, professional, and incredibly effective.
Why Nurses Need a Coaching Framework

Here is something no one tells nurses who transition to coaching: your clinical skills are not enough on their own. In nursing, you assess, plan, implement, and evaluate — but the patient is passive. In coaching, the client has to be an **active participant** in their own transformation. That requires a completely different approach.

Without a coaching framework, nurses default to 'telling' mode — giving advice, creating care plans, solving problems FOR the client. That is great nursing but terrible coaching. The D.E.P.T.H. Method teaches you to **guide, empower, and facilitate** — which is what actually creates lasting change.
The D.E.P.T.H. Method™ for Nurse Coaching
This framework will feel familiar because it mirrors the nursing process you already know — but adapted for coaching. Think of it as your care plan for coaching sessions.

steps.title: Discover
steps.description: Conduct a comprehensive wellness intake — similar to a nursing assessment but broader. Explore health history, current conditions, medications, lifestyle habits, stress levels, sleep quality, nutrition, exercise, emotional wellbeing, social support, and personal goals. Your clinical eye helps you catch things non-nurse coaches miss.

steps.title: Evaluate
steps.description: Map the client's situation against the 5 root causes. Is this primarily a health literacy gap? Behavior change resistance? Chronic stress? Post-treatment abandonment? Whole-person neglect? Most clients present with 2-3 interconnected root causes. Your nursing assessment skills make this step intuitive.

steps.title: Pinpoint
steps.description: Prioritize the most impactful area for initial focus. Unlike nursing where you triage by acuity, in coaching you triage by READINESS. Which change is the client most ready and motivated to make? Start there. Early wins build momentum and trust for bigger changes later.

steps.title: Transform
steps.description: Co-create an action plan with the client — not FOR them. Use motivational interviewing, habit stacking, accountability structures, and your clinical knowledge to guide practical, sustainable changes. Address nutrition, movement, stress management, sleep, medication adherence, and self-advocacy with their medical team.

steps.title: Heal
steps.description: Provide ongoing support, celebrate progress, adjust strategies, and help clients internalize their new health behaviors. This phase is about building health autonomy — teaching clients to manage their own wellness long-term. The ongoing relationship creates 3-6 months of recurring revenue per client.

checkpoint.question: In the D.E.P.T.H. Method for nurse coaching, how do you prioritize in the Pinpoint phase?

options.label: By medical acuity, like in clinical triage
By client readiness and motivation for change
By whichever issue is easiest to solve

checkpoint.successMessage: Yes! In coaching, you triage by readiness, not acuity. Starting with the change a client is most motivated to make builds early wins, momentum, and trust.

sections.content: D — Discover: The Wellness Intake

Your Discover session will feel like a thorough nursing assessment — but with more time and depth. You spend **60 to 90 minutes** understanding the whole person. Ask about their medical history, current conditions, medications, and treatments. Then go deeper: what does their typical day look like? How do they manage stress? What is their relationship with food? How well are they sleeping? What are they afraid of? What do they want their life to look like?

Your nursing assessment skills are your secret weapon in the Discover phase. You can catch red flags that non-nurse coaches miss — medication interactions, symptom patterns, signs that a client needs to see their doctor before proceeding with coaching. This clinical lens is what makes nurse coaches so valuable.
E — Evaluate: Your Clinical Edge

Once you have the full picture, evaluate which root causes are most active. A client recently discharged from heart surgery who is overwhelmed by their recovery plan has a **post-hospital abandonment** and **health literacy** problem. A nurse colleague who is burned out, stress-eating, and pre-diabetic has a **chronic stress** and **behavior change** problem. Your clinical knowledge helps you connect dots that other coaches cannot see.
Common client scenarios for nurse coaches:
items: **Post-surgical recovery** — Client needs guidance implementing discharge instructions, managing pain, rebuilding strength, and navigating follow-up care
**Chronic disease management** — Client with diabetes, hypertension, or autoimmune conditions needs lifestyle support to complement medical treatment
**Nurse burnout recovery** — Fellow nurses struggling with burnout, compassion fatigue, and unhealthy coping mechanisms need whole-person support
**Preventive wellness** — Client with family history of disease wants proactive lifestyle changes to reduce their risk
**Weight and metabolic health** — Client needs sustainable nutrition and movement guidance, not another crash diet

sections.content: P — Pinpoint: Starting with Readiness

The biggest shift for nurses entering coaching is moving from 'telling' to 'asking.' Instead of prescribing a plan, you ask: 'Of everything we have discussed, what feels most important to you right now?' and 'On a scale of 1 to 10, how ready are you to make that change?' **Start where the client's motivation is highest.** A client who is ready to improve their sleep will make that change faster than a client who 'knows' they should exercise but dreads it.

checkpoint.question: What is the biggest mindset shift for nurses transitioning to coaching?

options.label: Moving from 'telling' to 'asking' — empowering instead of prescribing

checkpoint.successMessage: Exactly! In coaching, you empower clients to take ownership of their health rather than prescribing plans for them. This shift from telling to asking is what drives lasting transformation.

sections.content: T — Transform: Co-Creating the Plan

In the Transform phase, you and your client build the action plan together. Use your clinical knowledge to inform the options, but let the client choose the path. If a diabetic client needs to reduce blood sugar, you might say: 'There are several approaches that work well. We could start with meal timing, reducing processed carbohydrates, adding a daily walk, or improving sleep quality. Which of those feels most doable for you this week?'
Transform phase strategies for nurse coaches:
items: **Motivational interviewing** — Ask powerful questions that help clients discover their own motivation for change
**Habit stacking** — Attach new health behaviors to existing routines for easier adoption
**Medication adherence support** — Help clients understand their medications and build systems for consistent compliance
**Stress management protocols** — Teach breathing techniques, boundary-setting, and stress-reduction practices
**Self-advocacy coaching** — Empower clients to communicate effectively with their medical team and ask the right questions

sections.content: H — Heal: Long-Term Wellness Autonomy

The Heal phase is about building your client's confidence and ability to manage their own health. This is the opposite of the dependency model in healthcare. You want your clients to eventually say: 'I know exactly what to do and I feel confident doing it.' This ongoing support phase typically spans **3 to 6 months**, creating substantial recurring revenue.

sections.content: Can you see yourself using your nursing expertise in a whole new way — coaching clients through real transformation?
What Is Coming Next

You now have the complete D.E.P.T.H. Method framework for nurse coaching. In the final lesson, you will learn exactly how to get your first paying clients — starting with the warm market of hospital colleagues, former patients, and community members who already trust your clinical expertise.

keyTakeaways: The D.E.P.T.H. Method adapts your nursing assessment skills into a coaching framework: Discover, Evaluate, Pinpoint, Transform, Heal
The biggest mindset shift is moving from 'telling' to 'asking' — empowering clients instead of prescribing plans
Prioritize by client READINESS, not medical acuity — start where motivation is highest to build early wins and momentum

lessons.title: How To Get Your First Clients
lessons.subtitle: Build a thriving nurse coaching practice from day one

sections.content: {name}, this is where everything comes together. You understand what nurse coaching is and why the world needs it (Lesson 1). You have the D.E.P.T.H. Method to guide every client (Lesson 2). Now let us talk about the part that every nurse worries about: how do I go from clinical professional to paid coaching practice?

Here is something that will surprise you: as a nurse, your warm market is BIGGER and more trusting than almost any other coach's. You have colleagues, former patients, patient families, community members, and an entire professional network that already sees you as a healthcare authority. Getting clients is about having the right conversations, not building a brand from scratch.
The Warm Market Strategy for Nurses

Your warm market is uniquely powerful because of your clinical background. People trust nurses more than almost any other profession — we have been rated the **most trusted profession** for over 20 years. That trust transfers directly to your coaching practice.
Your warm market as a nurse includes:
items: **Hospital and clinic colleagues** who are burned out, stressed, and struggling with their own health
**Former patients and their families** who need ongoing support after discharge
**Physician and provider contacts** who can refer patients who need coaching support
**Friends and family** who have always come to you with health questions
**Church, community, and social groups** where people know you as 'the nurse'
**Other nurses on social media** who are looking for a way out of burnout and bedside nursing

sections.content: The Conversation Framework

When a colleague or community member shares a health struggle, simply say: 'I just completed a professional certification in nurse coaching. I am working with a small number of clients to help them manage their health outside the clinical setting. Would you be open to a **free 20-minute Wellness Assessment** to see if coaching might help?' As a nurse, this offer carries instant credibility.

For fellow nurses struggling with burnout: 'I know what you are going through because I have been there. I just got certified in a coaching methodology that helps nurses take control of their own health and wellbeing. I would love to offer you a free 20-minute session to see if it could help you too.'

checkpoint.question: Why is a nurse's warm market uniquely powerful for getting coaching clients?

options.label: Nurses have more free time than other professionals
Nurses are rated the most trusted profession, and that trust transfers to coaching
Nurses have larger social media followings

checkpoint.successMessage: Exactly! Nurses have been rated the most trusted profession for over 20 years. That trust gives you an enormous advantage when transitioning to coaching.

sections.content: Pricing Your Services

Your clinical background commands premium pricing. Clients are paying for your nursing knowledge, coaching skills, and the personalized attention that the healthcare system cannot provide. Compare your coaching to a single ER visit ($2,000+), a specialist appointment ($300-500), or a month of medications ($200+). Your ongoing support that helps people AVOID those costs is incredibly valuable.
Recommended pricing structure for nurse coaches:
items: **Wellness Assessment:** Free (20 minutes to demonstrate your clinical + coaching edge)
**Single session:** $150 to $225 per session (higher than non-nurse coaches due to clinical expertise)
**90-Day Wellness Journey:** $347 per month for 3 months ($1,041 total) — 4 coaching calls, personalized wellness plan, symptom tracking, email support
**6-Month Health Transformation:** $447 per month for 6 months ($2,682 total) — bi-weekly calls, comprehensive lifestyle overhaul, medical team coordination support
**Nurse Burnout Recovery Program** (group, 6-8 nurses): $297 to $497 per person per month

sections.content: Your nursing credential justifies pricing **20-30% higher** than non-nurse coaches. Clients know they are getting someone with real clinical knowledge, not just someone who took an online course. Never apologize for your pricing — your expertise is worth every dollar.
Your Income Potential

The math is powerful. If you enroll just **5 clients per month** in a 90-Day Wellness Journey at **$347 per month**, that is **$1,735 per month**. Scale to 15 active clients and you are at **$5,205 per month**. Add a Nurse Burnout Recovery group with 8 nurses at **$397 each** and that is another **$3,176** per launch. Many nurse coaches reach **$6,000 to $10,000 per month** within their first year — more than most nursing salaries with half the hours and zero night shifts.
See what your monthly income could look like:

revealCard.teaser: See how an ICU nurse went from burnt out to earning $9,400/month as a coach...
revealCard.content: Kim was a 38-year-old ICU nurse who had worked bedside for 14 years. She was emotionally exhausted, physically broken, and seriously considering leaving healthcare entirely. After getting certified as a Nurse Life Coach, she started with two populations: her fellow nurses who were also burning out, and patients she had seen cycle through the ICU with preventable chronic conditions. She launched a Nurse Burnout Recovery group program and started taking individual chronic disease management clients. Within 6 months she had 22 active clients between individual and group programs, earning $9,400/month. She works 30 hours per week from home. Her exact words: 'I am still a nurse. I am just doing nursing the way it was always supposed to be done — with time, compassion, and real impact.'

checkpoint.question: Why can nurse coaches charge 20-30% more than non-nurse coaches?

options.label: Because they have more coaching certifications
Because clients value the clinical knowledge and medical credibility a nurse brings
Because nursing school was more expensive

checkpoint.successMessage: Correct! Your clinical expertise, medical vocabulary, and ability to spot red flags gives clients confidence that they are working with a credible health professional, not just a lifestyle coach.

sections.content: Scope of Practice Reminder

This is critical, {name}. In your coaching practice, you are operating under **coaching scope**, not your nursing license. You **educate** clients on health and wellness. You **guide** behavior change and lifestyle modifications. You **support** clients in implementing their medical team's recommendations. You **empower** clients to advocate for themselves. You **refer** to physicians, specialists, and mental health professionals for clinical care. Keeping coaching and nursing scope separate protects you legally and professionally.
Your 30-Day Launch Plan
Follow this plan to get your first nurse coaching clients within 30 days:
items: **Week 1:** List 20 people — colleagues, former patients, community members — who are struggling with health or burnout. Reach out to 5 with your free Wellness Assessment offer.
**Week 2:** Conduct free 20-minute assessments. Use the Discover phase to demonstrate your clinical + coaching expertise. Offer your 90-Day Wellness Journey to those who are ready.
**Week 3:** Share your certification journey on social media. Post about the nurse coaching movement. Connect with other nurses who are curious about coaching careers.
**Week 4:** Follow up with everyone you spoke to. Ask for referrals. Approach 2-3 local physicians about being a coaching resource for their patients who need lifestyle support.

sections.content: Can you picture yourself leaving the night shifts behind and building a coaching practice that uses your nursing skills in a whole new way — earning $5,000+ per month from home?
Your Next Step

You have completed all three lessons of your Nurse Coach Foundation training. You understand the healthcare gap that nurse coaching fills, you have the D.E.P.T.H. Method adapted for your clinical background, and you know exactly how to leverage your warm market to get your first paying clients. Take the certification exam to earn your **ASI-accredited credential** and start your new career.

You became a nurse because you wanted to help people. Burnout and a broken system tried to take that away from you. Nurse coaching gives it back — on YOUR terms, with YOUR schedule, at YOUR income level. Take the exam, get certified, and reach out to your first 5 contacts this week, {name}. They need your expertise.

keyTakeaways: Your nursing background gives you a uniquely powerful warm market — colleagues, former patients, physician referrals, and community trust
Nurse coaches can charge 20-30% more than non-nurse coaches due to clinical expertise and medical credibility
A 90-Day Wellness Journey at $347/month with 15 active clients generates over $5,200 per month from home
